text:
Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion,

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, I think that people tend to be more concerned about individual cases, whether human or animal, more so than statistics, so I am not surprised to hear that research subjects were more upset about the idea of a dog being beaten than the idea of a human being similarly beaten.  It is a simple fact that people are somewhat inured to violence against humans because we see so much of it in the media, and yet violence against charismatic animals such as dogs or seals is both shocking and upsetting to us.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, I think that people tend to be more concerned about individual cases, whether human or animal, more so than statistics, so I am not surprised to hear that research subjects were more upset about the idea of a dog being beaten than the idea of a human being similarly beaten.  It is a simple fact that people are somewhat inured to violence against humans because we see so much of it in the media, and yet violence against charismatic animals such as dogs or seals is both shocking and upsetting to us.  

We have to remember that this result came from a laboratory.  If people were in a real situation in which they could either stop an unfamiliar dog from being beaten, or a stranger from being beaten, I doubt that anyone would choose the dog.

I do not think that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering, simply because the former grabs our attention more acutely.  But I do think that we need to be careful not make decisions that have real-world consequences using only our feelings, rather than our rational thoughts.  For example, we might oppose the hunting of whales, yet if a small community of indigenous people are only able to survive through the winter by sustainably killing one whale per year for meat and blubber, then we should not let our idealistic view of noble, graceful animals distract from the needs of real, living persons.  

As for the other question of people preferring to save their own dog, rather than the life of a foreign tourist, I cannot really judge anyone too harshly.  How many of us could truly say that we would prefer to save a stranger over a family member?  Wouldn't you prefer to save your estranged uncle even if it meant allowing two or more other people to die as a result?  People are close to their pets, and treat them as family, so it is not surprising, or unethical, for us to prioritize their welfare.  My main objection is treating the vague idea of an animal as more valuable than the real-world welfare of a human.

Is It Wrong to Eat Meat?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, I think that people tend to be more concerned about individual cases, whether human or animal, more so than statistics, so I am not surprised to hear that research subjects were more upset about the idea of a dog being beaten than the idea of a human being similarly beaten.  It is a simple fact that people are somewhat inured to violence against humans because we see so much of it in the media, and yet violence against charismatic animals such as dogs or seals is both shocking and upsetting to us.  

We have to remember that this result came from a laboratory.  If people were in a real situation in which they could either stop an unfamiliar dog from being beaten, or a stranger from being beaten, I doubt that anyone would choose the dog.

I do not think that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering, simply because the former grabs our attention more acutely.  But I do think that we need to be careful not make decisions that have real-world consequences using only our feelings, rather than our rational thoughts.  For example, we might oppose the hunting of whales, yet if a small community of indigenous people are only able to survive through the winter by sustainably killing one whale per year for meat and blubber, then we should not let our idealistic view of noble, graceful animals distract from the needs of real, living persons.  

As for the other question of people preferring to save their own dog, rather than the life of a foreign tourist, I cannot really judge anyone too harshly.  How many of us could truly say that we would prefer to save a stranger over a family member?  Wouldn't you prefer to save your estranged uncle even if it meant allowing two or more other people to die as a result?  People are close to their pets, and treat them as family, so it is not surprising, or unethical, for us to prioritize their welfare.  My main objection is treating the vague idea of an animal as more valuable than the real-world welfare of a human.  

This, of course, leads to more philosophical questions, and ones that I cannot give a confident answer to.  For example, is it wrong to eat meat?  Humans benefit from the nutritional density of meat, but animals are obviously harmed.  I think that this is a personal choice that each individual should make, and one that they shouldn't make lightly.  As long as they are aware of the fact that animals suffer for their convenience, then (with some serious regulations in place to prevent extreme suffering) they should be allowed to do so.  Likewise, I tend to favor animal research for medical purposes, because ultimately, a lot more suffering is prevented than is caused.  But, of course, I accept that this is not always a utilitarian calculation.  Some may feel that it is wrong to deliberately harm an animal or a human, and I respect that opinion.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, I think that people tend to be more concerned about individual cases, whether human or animal, more so than statistics, so I am not surprised to hear that research subjects were more upset about the idea of a dog being beaten than the idea of a human being similarly beaten.  It is a simple fact that people are somewhat inured to violence against humans because we see so much of it in the media, and yet violence against charismatic animals such as dogs or seals is both shocking and upsetting to us.  

We have to remember that this result came from a laboratory.  If people were in a real situation in which they could either stop an unfamiliar dog from being beaten, or a stranger from being beaten, I doubt that anyone would choose the dog.

I do not think that it is wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering, simply because the former grabs our attention more acutely.  But I do think that we need to be careful not make decisions that have real-world consequences using only our feelings, rather than our rational thoughts.  For example, we might oppose the hunting of whales, yet if a small community of indigenous people are only able to survive through the winter by sustainably killing one whale per year for meat and blubber, then we should not let our idealistic view of noble, graceful animals distract from the needs of real, living persons.  

As for the other question of people preferring to save their own dog, rather than the life of a foreign tourist, I cannot really judge anyone too harshly.  How many of us could truly say that we would prefer to save a stranger over a family member?  Wouldn't you prefer to save your estranged uncle even if it meant allowing two or more other people to die as a result?  People are close to their pets, and treat them as family, so it is not surprising, or unethical, for us to prioritize their welfare.  My main objection is treating the vague idea of an animal as more valuable than the real-world welfare of a human.  

This, of course, leads to more philosophical questions, and ones that I cannot give a confident answer to.  For example, is it wrong to eat meat?  Humans benefit from the nutritional density of meat, but animals are obviously harmed.  I think that this is a personal choice that each individual should make, and one that they shouldn't make lightly.  As long as they are aware of the fact that animals suffer for their convenience, then (with some serious regulations in place to prevent extreme suffering) they should be allowed to do so.  Likewise, I tend to favor animal research for medical purposes, because ultimately, a lot more suffering is prevented than is caused.  But, of course, I accept that this is not always a utilitarian calculation.  Some may feel that it is wrong to deliberately harm an animal or a human, and I respect that opinion.

In so many words, I can understand why people tend to favor the lives of highly-visible animals over the lives of unseen humans, but I do have to strenuously object.  The needs of the many, as it were, far outweigh the needs of the few.
